April 13th was the last day for citizens of NC to register to vote in order to be able to vote in the state's May 8th primary.
The primary is separated by party, meaning only registered party members can vote in their party's primary.
NC voters will also vote on Amendment One on May 8th, which would add an amendment to the state's constitution banning same-sex marriage.

May we learn to give people room to adapt/adjust to how life has changed them even when those adaptations/adjustments make us uncomfortable.
What I care about is that I'm able to name changes in my behavior and understand where they came from. That is growth and it is progress.
Maybe I will be somewhere else with my language this time next year- I don't know and, honestly, I don't care.
If the worst vice I picked up coming out of these last 2 years is cussing more, then I'm okay with that.
It won't tho. Be fucking clear about that. #seewhatididthere
I get it. I do. I don't want this to dissolve into a respectability politics debate but I get it. We think language creates safe boundaries.
I receive messages from older women/women in ministry saying that, as a role model, I should watch what I say and stop cussing so much.
To be "grown" and "cool" as a kid, I would sneak and curse but I always made it feel foreign out of my mouth because it was supposed to.
Since birth, I wanted to be an AKA and the ones (young and old) I knew, before college, carried themselves/their speech in a regal way.
And in church, you were taught that godly women only use godly language.
I can count on one hand with FINGERS left the number of times in 33 years I heard my mother curse. She just didn't do it.
I was groomed in environments where cursing is not what polished women did. Women who are "common" cuss.
I legit cuss alot more than I ever did and I cuss publicly. She asked if this was something we wanted to work on and I said "No. I'm good."
The more I've been through, the more cussing I'm doing. I talked about that with my therapist today.
It's hard enough to navigate w/o parents. Don't make it harder by forcing us to navigate w/o folks who mean so much to us in other ways.
Pastors, don't take our moving to different cities/churches personally. If it didn't have anything to do with you, don't make it about you.
Many of us take pastoral relationships very seriously and it is never an easy decision to move churches.
I can definitely relate.
When he was battling addiction, his pastor became a dad to him and, after losing both his parents, this feels like another parental loss.
So the pastor has literally blocked him on social media and won't return his calls/texts.
He left the church because he moved away but the pastor felt like he still could have made the drive and was upset he chose not to do it.
...spent the morning talking to one of my homeboys who is experiencing church hurt.
So wait. Did they light a unity candle last night and I just missed it?!

And until dudes are ready to have that conversation, they can quit hashtagging Kenneka and every other sister because its clanging symbols.
But they are just as monstrous as some of the brothers who have taken some of our sisters away.
There are some men who will never see the inside of a prison simply because their treatment of women isn't considered criminal...
That's why yall's men's conferences and organizations will forever be bullshit. Because all your meetings have not materialized better men.
But every day, we get on here and hear what's wrong with "females"...as if we magically manifested all this pain ourselves.
Hearts broken. Spirits crushed. Hopes and dreams dashed. Bitterness, anger, hopelessness all take root.
...and it doesn't seem to matter until she is dead.
At any given moment, a Black girl/woman is living with/through the brokenness cause by someone in her intimate space...
Every 21 hours, a Black girl/woman is killed by someone who was in her intimate space...
If you do not hold the brothers accountable for their treatment of Black girls/women and justify their behavior, you are the forces of evil.
If you have left bodies of broken girls and women in your wake and have never apologized for the trauma you caused, Heaven is not your home.
If your personal ethic and theology doesn't compel you to make the world better for Black girls and women, you are the AntiChrist.
So where do we go to be free?
We are supposed to find rest and safety in those we love. Yet, they are often the ones who cause us the most terror.
...and I'm thinking myself and other sisters waking up everyday wiping tears, preparing to face a world that looks for ways to break us.
...and I'm thinking about Kennedi and all our little sisters who've known heartbreak before they've gotten a chance to know themselves.
...and thinking about Kenneka Jenkins and Jeannine Skinner who are no longer here because they trusted devils imitating angels.
I'm listening to Solange's "Weary" and wondering where do we go?
Where do Black girls go to be whole and safe and free?
For Kenneka Jenkins and all the Black Girl magicians who become ancestors before they fully get to become alchemists...we rage and we fight.

I hope you're being patient with them and, above all else, I hope they know you love them.
If you know people who have lost a parent (or person who raised them), I hope you are giving space/freedom to mourn/adjust to this new life.
Right now, I'm a daughter missing her mama. Right now, I'm a child who didn't think they'd have to have everything figured out so fast.
I believe some wounds reopen often and, if time does anything, it hopefully gives us more tools to maneuver through those instances.
Please don't tell me it gets better with time. Please don't tell me that's how wounds heal. Because I don't believe that.
Please don't tell me you can't imagine my pain. To me, it's actually insulting.
Every second of every single day, I miss her. And it hurts.
Something as simple as trying to figure out how to get new tires and a ride from the airport stings. Without her, I'm often lost.
Whether it is needing advice, wanting to celebrate successes, wishing she could talk me through heartache, I'm reminded she's gone.
My mother will celebrate her second birthday in Heaven on Saturday.   This world feels so big and cold and dark at times without her here.

Finding ways to understand how we can compliment each other professionally is definitely one of them.
There's so much about relationships that we have to unlearn in order to promote much healthier forms of intimacy.
And while my womanism doesn't allow me to criticize BW relationship choices, I understand the costs associated with that kind of decision.
I've seen sisters choose the route of adjusting/shaping their lives to be in relationships with men who didn't appreciate their full power.
What I do matters too and you need to be trying to figure out how you compliment me and that work instead of assuming I will change it.
Now, standing in the midst of things I've prepared for my whole life, I now understand why sisters say "I'm focused on my career."
Essentially, I denied my confidence to be connected with brothers who didn't know their own worth so they definitely couldn't see mine.
And I heard that, took it to heart and tried to dumb down my own work. Stopped writing and posting things to prove I could be THAT girl.
I was told #redliptheology makes me a dope colleague/great convo partner but not the woman who meets Mama &amp  sits on the church's second row.
And I did that. I would do everything I could to show that his life/what he had going on mattered. I never got the same in return.
We're taught our lives are supposed to take the shape of being helpmates and we'll be rewarded with a beautiful family.
A thread: Back when I was super saved, I'd say things like "I'll never be the kind of woman who says I'm too focused on my career for love."

Has someone done work around the ethics of loving and being in intimate relationship?

So, while there is alot in my life that isn't good right now, today I'm celebrating the fact that 6yrs ago, I walked away and kept walking.
I pray we heal and become well.
I would love to tell you I pray for him. Chile...I don't. LOL! i pray for us: the ones who have been hurt and have to heal.
And then get help. Seek counseling. Go to therapy. Six years later, I'm realizing I still haven't fully healed from things he said to me.
Talk to your parents, friends, loved ones. And get away. Seriously.
I used to think it wasn't bad because he wasn't hitting me and every day wasn't a bad day. But I was being abused and deserved better.
To anyone who is in an emotionally abusive relationship, please know that you are worth more than what you're being given right now.
Things ain't all good. Heartbreak came again. But, today, I can say that I'm proud of myself for having the courage to walk away from him.
So, though so much has happened in my life in these past 6 years that hurt, today I thank God I had the strength to walk away from him.
He told me I'm the kind of woman men look past waiting for something better. I cringe sometimes when I think what I believe/took from him.
His words and actions have stayed with me. They carried over into relationships after him. And he was never worth it.
I hope he's a better dude to his fiance. The fact that he could find humor in and the need to joke about my singleness says he's not.
Then I had to remember how God saved me from him. Literally delivered me from the hands of the enemy.
And for a split second, he almost got to me. I almost began to feel bad about still being single while he's about to get married.
I mean...he is still a Grade-A asshole.
Dude, however, is still a jerk. We ran into each other a few months back and we gloried in the fact he's engaged and I'm still single.
Professionally, I have done well and better than if I had stayed in that program with folks who didn't believe in me or my work.
I left that program, went to Duke and then PTS. It felt good to tell my former advisor that I'd done well after he told me I wouldn't.
Movers were at my townhouse by the time I flew back home. Mama told me ain't no man or piece of paper worth my peace.
I remember flying home crying and telling my mama everything: this program is horrible and this man is evil. I want to come home.
When I got the courage to leave, I was so embarrassed. What are people at home going to think? I'm leaving a PhD program. I have failed.
People often ignore the impact emotional and verbal abuse have because it doesn't leave visible scars.
i hid so much from my mama and friends. But, they knew. You can only hid so much.
...when he called, I came. Whatever he wanted, I gave it to him. All while he was telling me I was worthless.
...and this was the dude I was trying to make love me. The dude who told me nobody would care about me more than him.
He told me the only good thing I had going for myself was that I could write well and in print, no one would have to look at me.
I remember dude called me weak and unlovable. He told me I wasn't worth shit, it was my fault my dad was absent and I would never be loved.
It is not worth the pain of trying to make people love you who have decided to hate you.
I just said that to say: Go where you are and can be loved. Personally. Professionally. Spiritually. Physically. Emotionally. Financially.
It's been interesting to see how my life has changed in these 6yrs. Moving back was the single most defining moment of my life at the time.
I'm glad I had a mama who told me that I could always come home when I told her that I'd made a huge mistake.
It has taken (is still taking) me years to heal from that experience.
6yrs ago today, I moved back to NC after moving across the country to pursue a PhD in a program I hated and be w/an abusive man.
There is hope. There is always hope.
I spent the past few days wondering if I'll ever get married/become a mom. Then I spent yesterday w/couples and saw Halle is pregnant...

It doesn't help to be told that however you choose to heal further endangers other women. And it wasn't your fault to begin with.
Even in how we try to comfort sexual assault victims, we need to be careful not to perpetuate even more shame.
I was scared to report for a lot of reasons. Some of them, I own. Some of them aren't mine.
I've had folks ask me "why was he in your house? Where was your discernment? Have you not been praying?" It hurt and is hard to ignore.
And also, in 2017, we really don't make it easy for women to come forward about assault.
It's not my responsibility to make sure my rapist doesn't rape anyone else. It's his and his alone.
Mostly, this has come from the men in my life who love me. I get they want to protect me. But still.
But I kinda get pissed when people say to me, "what about your responsibility to other women? What if he does this to someone else?"
On some level, I still blame myself and am working through it.
I had my reasons for not reporting/calling the police. Admittedly, they were rooted in fear and my own shame for inviting him into my home.
I chose not to report my sexual assault (dude has since been arrested for something else) but I've grown tired of folks telling me I'm wrong

"God don't want no coward soldiers."- #WhatTheyTaughtMeInMyLiturgylessTraditionThatPreferredExperienceOverScriptureTheyHadToBeReadInto
If you can't recognize that, in this time, we need to be equipped with various ways to affirm and protect all people, what God do you serve?
Nevertheless, this ain't an argument over academic freedom. It's about the humanity and dignity of all peoples.
...and yet, I understand it's par for the course of being a Black academic.
It's been hard to see faculty I care about get dragged because they care about humanity.
Critiques of *how* diversity/inclusion training works aside, the moment we negate the need to learn about others, we blaspheme the Divine.
That means we must interrogate the ways we do not affirm/live into that.
The aim of Christian theological education, I believe, should strive towards teaching us how to do life together.
Any theological professor/Christian intellectual who says diversity/inclusion has no place in theology doesn't know Jesus.
Taking my Duke Div education (in/out of class seriously), I was equipped with the resources necessary to do the work of liberation.
Yet, while at Duke Div, I was given the best tools necessary to critique the racist theological underpinnings of American Christianity.
That these experiences were at Div School are, both, extremely disheartening and indicative of how 45 could be beloved by White Christians.
And while at Duke, I had countless encounters with racism and intersectional oppression.
I went to Duke with no illusions that this place was designed for/cared about me. It is called "the plantation", after all.
I also believe that giants die and want to be a part of the work that challenges Seminary students to walk away from oppressive theologies.
That is possible. It really is.
Committed to theological education, I hope I will embody the kind of scholarship that reflects God's intention for creation.
Sometimes, I feel like that narrative from the student/alumni perspective gets lost or is not present.
It's not the blatant racism of days old but something more seductive, covert and dangerous.
My experience at Duke could really be summed up as an experience with liberal and Evangelical White people who don't think they're racist.
...another one said slavery provided employment and salvation for Africans that they would have otherwise been denied.
Once, a White classmate said Howard Thurman needed to be "disciplined" against the church fathers before his work could be validated.
...or asking the question, "What is the merit of faith traditions that value experience over scripture?"
Racism comes in the form of questioning the legitimacy of faith traditions because they are not tethered to "liturgy".
Yet, I do think it's important it's come to the "light" because of how covert, seductive and sophisticated racism is among White Christians.
So, when I hear that professors are against diversity/inclusion as a matter of academic freedom, I'm not surprised. At all.
I got my MDiv from Duke Div. My time there was so formational to my understanding of how pervasive racism is within American Christianity.

@AudraSunshine I think there are some things that are not good and are evil that don't get redeemed.
@AudraSunshine I hear you. I think we trivialize that, too.
The church is imperfect. So are millennials. We meet at the foot of the cross together. And we need each other.
Church folk have saved my life these last two years. I mean that.
...and I say this as someone who recognizes that if it were not for church folk praying and caring for me, I literally would not be here.
I say this as someone who cut my professional writing teeth critiquing/picking apart the Black Church...
Also let me say: I get the millennial vs church critique. At the same time, I hope we can learn the ways in which church life matters.
Again, may not be your process. But it is mine.
Still, part of my healing has included asking of myself, "What have you lost and, of that, what did you actually need to lose?"
And I struggle with how "all things work together" for my good. I believe some things cannot be redeemed in the way we think that means.
I don't want to justify hurt or the things that have happened to me. Be clear. I never want to do that.
I don't want to remain in the wilderness -so to speak- but I do want to keep before me the lessons I am learning in this place.
Warsan Shire prays, "if it will keep my heart soft, break my heart every day." I don't know if I share this prayer but I understand it.
This wilderness that signifies death in all its forms somehow does not consume me but works to make me new that I might live again.
...and yet, it has been in this space of no control that I wonder if I'm exactly where I'm supposed to be.
Every kind of death has found me and forced itself into my life in ways that stripped me from the control over my life I thought I had.
I don't have the answers. I have just been thinking about all the ways I have been unmade in these last 2 years.
When we are unmade, when we lose sovereignty and enter the wilderness, perhaps- that's when we really begin to live.
I think there is a holiness in being unmade. I cannot yet articulate it but I think there is.
...but yet, you do not die. Death surrounds you but it does not win.
...the process of being unmade-of relinquishing sovereignty and acknowledging the vulnerability of your self to the powers that index death.
While I will never believe that it is God's will that we experience certain unspeakable horrors, I wonder if the process can still be holy.
Yet, I wonder if that is who God means for us to be.
We desire for self possession. It's seductive. And for marginalized folks, it matters to be able to name and hold yourself for yourself.
I've been thinking a lot about how I have become "unmade"...in a sense, losing the sovereignty that I thought I had over myself.
As I'm working through my stuff towards healing, I keep thinking about what it theologically means to "consent not to be a single being"...

It looks impossible but I know I will make it. And so will you.   There is grace in the dust for us.
It would've made an already excruciating  experience much worse. Yet now, I get to survey the landscape- though destroyed- with new vision.
While I knew nothing would ever be the same once Ma passed, there are some things I would not have been capable of dealing with last year.
Maybe we don't thank God enough for the dust. We don't recognize the inability to see the full scope of a thing all at once as God's care.
Yet, there is something oddly inspiring about it all. I *get* to construct a new life and way forward.
And at the same time, aspects of this year are uniquely difficult. I can *see* things. I know what has been broken and what cannot be fixed.
Last year was completely about survival- how (or if) I would make it. If I can make it through 2016, I can make it through anything.
I've been describing this year as "dust settling". After disaster/explosion, one can't survey damage/what to rebuild until the dust settles.

Happy Valentine's Day, y'all. I hope love finds its way to you in some capacity.
All I know is I see all of us. Some days, seeing all of us is all I got. Maybe that's enough. Maybe it's just good to know we're not alone.
And I reject those "in time, it will" narratives that work to diminish what we actually feel.
I don't know if/when lasting love will find us- those of us still looking for it.
Naming all of that, in part, is the only road to freedom.
Be clear. The church is largely responsible for my singleness.
And I'm even more unapologetic about holding the Church accountable for false teachings that bruise and wound.
Now, more than I ever have, I desire lasting love and the creation of family. And I'm unapologetic. I don't let anyone tell me it's wrong.
I know what it feels like to be changed because of the lack of good love in ways you can't share or be honest about.
I am a woman. I know what heartbreak looks like. I know what it feels to invest and not see a return.
I think that's where we are best able to recognize and embrace the fullness of who we are.  Finding them ain't as easy as it sounds, tho.
I'm more invested in encouraging Black women to seek, acknowledge and flourish within healing spaces of intimacy.
Last night, on a panel about Black love, I said I'm not interested at all in teaching abstinence and celibacy to Black women.
That thang ain't easy, tho.
I've spent a lot of time thinking through how love will be a part of my life and how I must always stay within a posture of wholeness.
Though one is for Valentine's Day, I didn't know both of my pieces would come out today. It's actually rather fitting and divine.

What about dating while living with HIV? Identity making while living with HIV? Stigma management? Social support &amp  what that looks like?
We also have to shift from just researching disease prevention to improving quality of life for people living with diseases
Some docs fall into trap of treating disease rather than treating people. @2BeatHIV tries to preempt that by involving the pub in decisions
To be honest, many PLWH aren't even concerned ab being Poz so much as they are worried ab cancer, diabetes, drug abuse, police violence
Feedback 4m PLWH tells us that they r more than their disease. They are HUMANS with lives, fams, desires, jobs, other interests &amp  challenges
It makes sense given our political current climate, but we also have to remember that the push to treat patients as PEOPLE FIRST is new
Surprisingly, ppl who know me tell me that these ideals aren't always translated to all research, health care, or businesses
Not trying to downplay it but I see my work as just a natural extension of my personality: care for others, have fun, empower together
The past few days I've been trying to figure out y people r so excited ab my work. I love what I do but it seems normal, natural...basic

Big Qs: Is it a medical benefit to ppl to stop therapy if they have undetectable virus load. Maybe not bc of possibility of resurge of virus
As a teen, MS baby has had some virus rebound - prob 4m HIV virus hiding in reservoirs of cells, but now undetectable w treatment #HIVcure
This gave researchers hope that early and aggressive treatment of HIV would be one way to eliminate virus #HIVcure
Mississippi baby was a case of a child born with HIV, aggressively treated w medication, &amp  virus was suppressed #HIVcure
They recently found that Vorinostat pushed multiple viruses out of reservoirs, may be useful to kill hiding HIV cells #HIVcure
Vorinostat is one type of treatment researchers are using to find HIV virus hiding in cell reservoirs to kill them #HIVcure
There are now ways to measuring HIV RNA particles in cells, researchers want to find reservoirs of HIV hiding in cells #HIVcure
Researchers testing whether genetic splicing (cutting HIV virus from cells) may protect cells from making HIV-1 virus #HIVcure
Listening to David Margolis discuss recent findings from IAS conference #HIVcure

8 yrs ago when I started grad school, I never thought I wld have a postdoc examining the use of technology in HIV cure community engagement
This includes academia, y'all. Yup. PhD's tooâ€¦
Think about it: In the next five years, if you don't know how to use technology in your career, you might lose it
I recently had a sobering convo with an exec at Cisco who said in the next 5 years, there will be 60million unfilled jobs related to tech
Have you all started to think about how you can incorporate technology into your work/careers?
